Potential Pitfalls

Though there are benefits, there are also many pitfalls to game-based learning. If not integrated properly, problems may ensue. Hover over each image for a description of the potential pitfalls.

Competition

Learning can become competitive. Students may try to cheat to cut corners to get ahead of their classmates. Games should be chosen that encourage competition against oneself.

Anxiety

The timers and competition incorporated into many games can cause anxiety in some students. Anxiety can cause the frontal cortex to shut down and thus inhibit learning. Ensure you know your students before introducing a game that may be stressful.

Addiction

Like with any video game, there is always the potential of becoming addicted to the game. Teachers should put a time limit that students spend on the video game.

Danger of extrinsic motivation

Though game-based learning often increases intrinsic motivation, too much emphasis on points or badges can lead to extrinsic motivation.

Boring or complicated storyline

A rich virtual is needed to engage students. They need to understand the narrative and feel themselves come alive in the game. Worthwhile games consist of more than just the game elements of points and levels. Ensure the storyline is interesting but understandable by playing the game yourself. Ask yourself, will students want to invest thought and time into this game? Can they empathize with the characters?

Cost

Most games require a paid subscription to play. Seek out which games your school already pays for, or apply for a grant.
